'''William Clarke''' (March 21, 1951 - November 3, 1996) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[harmonica]] player. He was chiefly associated with the [[Chicago blues]] style of [[Amplifier|amplified]] harmonica, but also incorporated elements of [[soul jazz]] and [[swing jazz|swing]] into his playing.

==Biography==
[[File:Bluesnews Ausgabe 01.jpg|thumb|Clarke on a magazine cover]]
{{Expand section|critical reception, music style|date=December 2009}}
Born in [[Inglewood, California|Inglewood]], [[California]], [[United States]], Clarke played guitar and drums as a youngster and learned the blues through [[The Rolling Stones]] [[gramophone record|records]]. He began playing harmonica in 1967 and played locally in [[Los Angeles]], while he held a day job as a [[machinist]]. He soon struck up an association with [[George "Harmonica" Smith]]; the pair began playing regularly together in 1977, lasting until Smith died in 1983.<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 101
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> 

Clarke began releasing albums in 1978 on small local [[record label]]s. From 1985 to 1988, [[Rick Holmstrom]] toured and played with Clarke.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p87585/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Rick Holmstrom biography by Char Ham |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=October 8, 2011}}</ref> In 1987, Clarke was nominated for a [[Blues Music Awards|W.C. Handy Award]] for his record ''Tip of the Top'', and after sending a [[demo tape]] to [[Alligator Records]], he secured a national [[recording contract]]. His debut for Alligator, ''Blowin' Like Hell'', arrived in 1990, and he followed the release with international [[concert tour|touring]]. "Must Be Jelly", a song from the album, won the Handy Award for Blues Song of the Year.

Clarke was touring in March 1996 when he [[Collapse (medical)|collapsed]] on stage at a date in [[Indianapolis]]. He was diagnosed with [[heart failure|congestive heart failure]], and as a result lost weight and cut back on [[alcohol]] and [[Recreational drug use|drug]]s.<ref name=amg>Steve Huey, [{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p309/biography|pure_url=yes}} William Clarke] at [[Allmusic]]</ref> These measures were not sufficient to keep him healthy; he collapsed again in November, at a [[concert]] in [[Fresno, California|Fresno]], and died of a bleeding [[Peptic ulcer|ulcer]], at the age of 45, the following day.<ref name=amg/>
